segment.source: This article describes how to quickly display the camera preview stream within a XAML page in a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: This article describes how to quickly display the camera preview stream within a XAML page in a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: Simple camera preview access
segment.target: Simple camera preview access

segment.source: Simple camera preview access
segment.target: Simple camera preview access

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This article describes how to quickly display the camera preview stream within a XAML page in a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: This article describes how to quickly display the camera preview stream within a XAML page in a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: Creating an app that captures photos and videos using the camera requires you to perform tasks like handling device and camera orientation or setting encoding options for the captured file.
segment.target: Creating an app that captures photos and videos using the camera requires you to perform tasks like handling device and camera orientation or setting encoding options for the captured file.

segment.source: For some app scenarios, you may want to just simply show the preview stream from the camera without worrying about these other considerations.
segment.target: For some app scenarios, you may want to just simply show the preview stream from the camera without worrying about these other considerations.

segment.source: This article shows you how to do that with a minimum of code.
segment.target: This article shows you how to do that with a minimum of code.

segment.source: Note that you should always shut down the preview stream properly when you are done with it by following the steps below.
segment.target: Note that you should always shut down the preview stream properly when you are done with it by following the steps below.

segment.source: For information on writing a camera app that captures photos or videos, see Capture photos and video with MediaCapture.
segment.target: For information on writing a camera app that captures photos or videos, see Capture photos and video with MediaCapture.

segment.source: Add capability declarations to the app manifest
segment.target: Add capability declarations to the app manifest

segment.source: In order for your app to access a device's camera, you must declare that your app uses the webcam and microphone device capabilities.
segment.target: In order for your app to access a device's camera, you must declare that your app uses the webcam and microphone device capabilities.

segment.source: If you want to save captured photos and videos to the users's Pictures or Videos library, you must also declare the picturesLibrary and videosLibrary capability.
segment.target: If you want to save captured photos and videos to the users's Pictures or Videos library, you must also declare the picturesLibrary and videosLibrary capability.

segment.source: Add capabilities to the app manifest
segment.target: Add capabilities to the app manifest

segment.source: In Microsoft Visual Studio, in Solution Explorer, open the designer for the application manifest by double-clicking the package.appxmanifest item.
segment.target: In Microsoft Visual Studio, in Solution Explorer, open the designer for the application manifest by double-clicking the package.appxmanifest item.

segment.source: Select the Capabilities tab.
segment.target: Select the Capabilities tab.

segment.source: Check the box for Webcam and the box for Microphone.
segment.target: Check the box for Webcam and the box for Microphone.

segment.source: For access to the Pictures and Videos library check the boxes for Pictures Library and the box for Videos Library.
segment.target: For access to the Pictures and Videos library check the boxes for Pictures Library and the box for Videos Library.

segment.source: Add a CaptureElement to your page
segment.target: Add a CaptureElement to your page

segment.source: Use a CaptureElement to display the preview stream within your XAML page.
segment.target: Use a CaptureElement to display the preview stream within your XAML page.

segment.source: CaptureElement
segment.target: CaptureElement

segment.source: Use MediaCapture to start the preview stream
segment.target: Use MediaCapture to start the preview stream

segment.source: The MediaCapture object is your app's interface to the device's camera.
segment.target: The MediaCapture object is your app's interface to the device's camera.

segment.source: This class is a member of the Windows.Media.Capture namespace.
segment.target: This class is a member of the Windows.Media.Capture namespace.

segment.source: The example in this article also uses APIs from the Windows.ApplicationModel and System.Threading.Tasks namespaces, in addition to those included by the default project template.
segment.target: The example in this article also uses APIs from the Windows.ApplicationModel and System.Threading.Tasks namespaces, in addition to those included by the default project template.

segment.source: CaptureElement
segment.target: CaptureElement

segment.source: Declare a class variable for the MediaCapture object.
segment.target: Declare a class variable for the MediaCapture object.

segment.source: SimpleCameraPreviewUsing
segment.target: SimpleCameraPreviewUsing

segment.source: Create a new instance of the MediaCapture class and call InitializeAsync to initialize the capture device.
segment.target: Create a new instance of the MediaCapture class and call InitializeAsync to initialize the capture device.

segment.source: This method may fail, on devices that don't have a camera for example, so you should call it from within a try block.
segment.target: This method may fail, on devices that don't have a camera for example, so you should call it from within a try block.

segment.source: An UnauthorizedAccessException will be thrown when you attempt to initialize the camera if the user has disabled camera access in the device's privacy settings.
segment.target: An UnauthorizedAccessException will be thrown when you attempt to initialize the camera if the user has disabled camera access in the device's privacy settings.

segment.source: You will also see this exception during development if you have neglected to add the proper capabilities to your app manifest.
segment.target: You will also see this exception during development if you have neglected to add the proper capabilities to your app manifest.

segment.source: Connect the MediaCapture to the CaptureElement by setting the Source property.
segment.target: Connect the MediaCapture to the CaptureElement by setting the Source property.

segment.source: Finally, start the preview by calling StartPreviewAsync.
segment.target: Finally, start the preview by calling StartPreviewAsync.

segment.source: DeclareMediaCapture
segment.target: DeclareMediaCapture

segment.source: Shut down the preview stream
segment.target: Shut down the preview stream

segment.source: When you are done using the preview stream, you should always shut down the stream and properly dispose of the associated resources to ensure that the camera is available to other apps on the device.
segment.target: When you are done using the preview stream, you should always shut down the stream and properly dispose of the associated resources to ensure that the camera is available to other apps on the device.

segment.source: The required steps for shutting down the preview stream are:
segment.target: The required steps for shutting down the preview stream are:

segment.source: Call StopPreviewAsync to stop the preview stream.
segment.target: Call StopPreviewAsync to stop the preview stream.

segment.source: Set the Source property of the CaptureElement to null.
segment.target: Set the Source property of the CaptureElement to null.

segment.source: Call the MediaCapture object's Dispose method to release the object.
segment.target: Call the MediaCapture object's Dispose method to release the object.

segment.source: Set the MediaCapture member variable to null.
segment.target: Set the MediaCapture member variable to null.

segment.source: CleanupCameraAsync
segment.target: CleanupCameraAsync

segment.source: You should shut down the preview stream when the user navigates away from your page by overriding the OnNavigatedFrom method.
segment.target: You should shut down the preview stream when the user navigates away from your page by overriding the OnNavigatedFrom method.

segment.source: OnNavigatedFrom
segment.target: OnNavigatedFrom

segment.source: You should also shut down the preview stream properly when your app is suspending.
segment.target: You should also shut down the preview stream properly when your app is suspending.

segment.source: To do this, register a handler for the Application.Suspending event in your page's constructor.
segment.target: To do this, register a handler for the Application.Suspending event in your page's constructor.

segment.source: RegisterSuspending
segment.target: RegisterSuspending

segment.source: In the Suspending event handler, first check to make sure that the page is being displayed the application's Frame by comparing the page type to the CurrentSourcePageType property.
segment.target: In the Suspending event handler, first check to make sure that the page is being displayed the application's Frame by comparing the page type to the CurrentSourcePageType property.

segment.source: If the page is not currently being displayed, then the OnNavigatedFrom event should already have been raised and the preview stream shut down.
segment.target: If the page is not currently being displayed, then the OnNavigatedFrom event should already have been raised and the preview stream shut down.

segment.source: If the page is currently being displayed, get a SuspendingDeferral object from the event args passed into the handler to make sure the system does not suspend your app until the preview stream has been shut down.
segment.target: If the page is currently being displayed, get a SuspendingDeferral object from the event args passed into the handler to make sure the system does not suspend your app until the preview stream has been shut down.

segment.source: After shutting down the stream, call the deferral's Complete method to let the system continue suspending your app.
segment.target: After shutting down the stream, call the deferral's Complete method to let the system continue suspending your app.

segment.source: SuspendingHandler
segment.target: SuspendingHandler

segment.source: Capture a still image from the preview stream
segment.target: Capture a still image from the preview stream

segment.source: It's simple to get a still image from the media capture preview stream in the form of a SoftwareBitmap.
segment.target: It's simple to get a still image from the media capture preview stream in the form of a SoftwareBitmap.

segment.source: For more information, see Get a preview frame.
segment.target: For more information, see Get a preview frame.
